title: Tools for Creating .json files for AlphaFold 3
text:
AlphaFold3 .json Creator
Unlike AlphaFold2, AlphaFold3 allows users to analyse more complex protein interactions e.g. with ligands or nucleotides. As such, we have created a python script to simplify the generation of .json files that are submitted to AlphaFold3 on the HPC.
crumbs: 1  Tools for Creating .json files for AlphaFold 3

title: Tools for Creating .json files for AlphaFold 3
text:
Installation
No installation required, simply source the package:
source package af3_tools-0.0.3
crumbs: 1  Tools for Creating .json files for AlphaFold 3

title: Tools for Creating .json files for AlphaFold 3
text:
Dependencies
These scripts have some dependencies. The file environment.yaml can be used to create a new mamba environment that has all the required packages and tools. See the RC documentation or the bioinformatics team for help if you don’t know how to set up mamba in your home directory.

title: Tools for Creating .json files for AlphaFold 3
text:
Detailed Instructions for .json Creation
Given the different complex variations, we have put documentation on using the script for the different scenarios within this blog post. Please use the links below for your specific use case.
Protein-Ligand Interactions
Protein-Protein Interactions
Protein-Nucleotide Interactions
Multi-Component Interactions
crumbs: 1  Tools for Creating .json files for AlphaFold 3

title: 2  Using af3_json_creator.py for Protein-Ligand Analyses
text:
FASTA Files
Standard FASTA format for proteins:
>protein_1
MALGRYGELITDLRSLVMEYPYDEWFHAQLMLALGKAGRRGEALHVYHKVRRLLRDELGLDPSHD
>protein_2
MDFKALGPIRAVNDRLAYTPSAPKVKQVLALLVMRANQIVSLESILDELWGDALPRTAVT


SMILES Files
One SMILES string per line, optionally with tab-separated names:
CCO ethanol
c1ccccc1    benzene
CC(=O)O acetic_acid
Or simple format (names will be auto-generated):
CCO
c1ccccc1
CC(=O)O
Note: SMILES information can be obtained from Pubchem https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/ for many things.

title: 2  Using af3_json_creator.py for Protein-Ligand Analyses
text:
Pairwise Combinations
Pairwise combinations will take all proteins within a FASTA file and all ligands within a SMILES file and generate corresponding .json files.
From the above example input files 6 .json files would be generated:
protein_1_ethanol.json
protein_1_benzene.json
protein_1_acetic_acid.json
protein_2_ethanol.json
protein_2_benzene.json
protein_2_acetic_acid.json
To create pairwise combinations of proteins with ligands:
python af3_json_creator.py protein-ligand --fasta proteins.fasta --smiles ligands.smi --output-dir output

title: 2  Using af3_json_creator.py for Protein-Ligand Analyses
text:
Protein-Ligand Multimer Combinations
Multimer combinations requires a configuration file. This file allows the user to specify the protein and ligand combinations. It is laid out as:
# Format: protein_list: group_name
protein_1, protein_2: heterodimer
protein_1, protein_2, protein_3: trimer
protein_1: monomer
Where your input FASTA file would have three proteins: protein_1, protein_2 and protein_3. If provided with a single ligand the .json files produced would be:
heterodimer_ethanol.json
trimer_ethanol.json
monomer_ethanol.json
Providing a file with multiple ligands will generate .json files with the specified multimer combinations for each individual ligand.
To generate .json files with multimer configuration:
python af3_json_creator.py protein-ligand --fasta proteins.fasta --smiles ligands.smi --config multimer.txt --output-dir output
For more complex protein-ligand combinations, please see Multi-Component Interactions.

title: 3  Using af3_json_creator.py for Protein-Protein Analyses
text:
FASTA Files
Standard FASTA format for proteins:
>protein_1
MALGRYGELITDLRSLVMEYPYDEWFHAQLMLALGKAGRRGEALHVYHKVRRLLRDELGLDPSHD
>protein_2
MDFKALGPIRAVNDRLAYTPSAPKVKQVLALLVMRANQIVSLESILDELWGDALPRTAVT

title: 3  Using af3_json_creator.py for Protein-Protein Analyses
text:
Pairwise Combinations
Pairwise combinations will take all proteins within the first supplied FASTA file and all proteins within the second supplied FASTA file and generate corresponding .json files.
Therefore, if the users has a FASTA file containing:
>protein_1
MALGRYGELITDLRSLVMEYPYDEWFHAQLMLALGKAGRRGEALHVYHKVRRLLRDELGLDPSHD
>protein_2
MDFKALGPIRAVNDRLAYTPSAPKVKQVLALLVMRANQIVSLESILDELWGDALPRTAVT
With a second FASTA file containing:
>protein_3
MESNNISEQTRNGIREKAKQGKLITTHAPFGYRYKQGHFVVHEEEAYTV
>protein_4
MKRLLQDVKDNKIEIVLSWKLNRISRSMRDVFNIIHEFKEHGVGYKSISENIDTSNASGEV
They would obtain 4 .json files:
protein_1_protein_3.json
protein_1_protein_4.json
protein_1_protein_3.json
protein_2_protein_4.json
To create pairwise combinations of single proteins:
python af3_json_creator.py protein-protein --fasta1 proteins_1.fasta --fasta2 proteins_2.fasta --output-dir output

title: 3  Using af3_json_creator.py for Protein-Protein Analyses
text:
Single Protein Multimers
To generate a single protein multimer .json then the user provides a a single FASTA file containing all the protein sequences they wish to examine as a multimer:
>protein_1
MALGRYGELITDLRSLVMEYPYDEWFHAQLMLALGKAGRRGEALHVYHKVRRLLRDELGLDPSHD
>protein_2
MDFKALGPIRAVNDRLAYTPSAPKVKQVLALLVMRANQIVSLESILDELWGDALPRTAVT
>protein_3
MESNNISEQTRNGIREKAKQGKLITTHAPFGYRYKQGHFVVHEEEAYTV
>protein_4
MKRLLQDVKDNKIEIVLSWKLNRISRSMRDVFNIIHEFKEHGVGYKSISENIDTSNASGEV
This would generate a single .json file:
protein_1_multimer_4.json
To produce a .json file for a single multimer complex:
python af3_json_creator.py protein-protein --fasta1 multi_proteins.fasta --output-dir output

title: 3  Using af3_json_creator.py for Protein-Protein Analyses
text:
Protein-Protein Multimer Combinations
Multiple multimer combinations require a configuration file. This file allows the user to specify the protein multimer combinations. It is laid out as:
# Format: protein_list: group_name
protein_1, protein_2: heterodimer
protein_1, protein_2, protein_3: trimer
protein_1, protein_1: monomer
Where your input FASTA file would have three proteins: protein_1, protein_2 and protein_3. The produced .json files would be:
heterodimer.json
trimer.json
monomer.json
To generate .json files with multimer configuration:
python af3_json_creator.py protein-protein --fasta1 multi_proteins.fasta --config multimer.txt --output-dir output
For more complex protein-protein combinations, please see Multi-Component Interactions.

title: 4  Using af3_json_creator.py for Protein-Nucleotide Analyses
text:
FASTA Files
Standard FASTA format for proteins:
>protein_1
MALGRYGELITDLRSLVMEYPYDEWFHAQLMLALGKAGRRGEALHVYHKVRRLLRDELGLDPSHD
>protein_2
MDFKALGPIRAVNDRLAYTPSAPKVKQVLALLVMRANQIVSLESILDELWGDALPRTAVT
DNA:
>dna_1
AGAGCGTTTAAGATCATGCGGGGAGAAGCGTACCACAAATAAAACTAAAAAATAGATTGCAAAAAATATA
>dna_2
ATAGAGCATTTAAGATTATGCGTGGAGAAGCATATCATAAATGATGCGGTTTTTCAGCCGCTTCATAAAG
or RNA:
>rna_1
AGAGCGUUUAAGAUCAUGCGGGGAGAAGCGUACCACAAAUAAAACUAAAAAAUAGAUUGCAAAAAAUAUA
>rna_2
AUAGAGCAUUUAAGAUUAUGCGUGGAGAAGCAUAUCAUAAAUGAUGCGGUUUUUCAGCCGCUUCAUAAAG

title: 4  Using af3_json_creator.py for Protein-Nucleotide Analyses
text:
Pairwise Combinations
Pairwise combinations will take all proteins within a FASTA file and all nucleotide sequences within a FASTA file and generate corresponding .json files.
From the above example input files of proteins with DNA, 4 .json files would be generated:
protein_1_dna_1.json
protein_1_dna_2.json
protein_2_dna_1.json
protein_2_dna_2.json
To create pairwise combinations of proteins with DNA:
python af3_json_creator.py protein-dna --fasta proteins.fasta --fasta-nucleic dna_sequences.fasta --output-dir output
Or to create pairwise combinations of proteins with DNA:
python af3_json_creator.py protein-rna --fasta proteins.fasta --fasta-nucleic rna_sequences.fasta --output-dir output

title: 4  Using af3_json_creator.py for Protein-Nucleotide Analyses
text:
Protein-Nucleotide Multimer Combinations
Multimer combinations requires a configuration file. This file allows the user to specify the protein and nucleotide combinations. It is laid out as:
# Format: protein_list: group_name
protein_1, protein_2: heterodimer
protein_1, protein_2, protein_3: trimer
protein_1: monomer
Where your input FASTA file would have three proteins: protein_1, protein_2 and protein_3. If provided with a single DNA or RNA sequence the .json files produced would be:
heterodimer_nucleotide.json
trimer_nucleotide.json
monomer_nucleotide.json
Providing a file with multiple nucleotide sequences will generate .json files with the specified multimer combinations for each individual nucleotide.
To generate .json files with multimer configuration for DNA:
python af3_json_creator.py protein-dna --fasta proteins.fasta --fasta-nucleic dna_sequences.fasta --config multimer.txt --output-dir output
Or to generate .json files with multimer configuration for RNA:
python af3_json_creator.py protein-rna --fasta proteins.fasta --fasta-nucleic rna_sequences.fasta --config multimer.txt --output-dir output
For more complex protein-nucleotide combinations, please see Multi-Component Interactions.

title: 5  Using af3_json_creator.py for Multi-Component Analyses
text:
# Basic example
python af3_json_creator.py create-example-yaml

# Advanced example with modifications
python af3_json_creator.py create-example-yaml --advanced

title: 5  Using af3_json_creator.py for Multi-Component Analyses
text:
5.1 Generating .json Using Example Configuration .yaml
Once the user has the example config .yaml they need to modify it to provide the name of the input files. For example, if working with the default example config .yaml, then the following lines would need to be modified:
complexes:
  - name: transcription_complex # modify to the name you want
    components:
      - type: protein
        file: transcription_factor.fasta # Provide path to input
      - type: dna
        file: promoter.fasta # Provide path to input
      - type: ligand
        file: cofactor.smi # Provide path to input
  
  - name: enzyme_complex # Delete if not need or copy to add more
    components:
      - type: protein
        file: enzyme1.fasta
      - type: protein
        file: enzyme2.fasta
      - type: ion
        ccdCodes: '[Mg+2]'
      - type: ligand
        file: substrate.smi
Once the example config .yaml has been edited for the users specific use case, then it can be provided to af3_json_creator.py as below:
python af3_json_creator.py multi-complex --config complex_config.yaml --output-dir output

title: 2  Using af3_json_creator.py for Protein-Ligand Analyses
text:
Input File Formats
af3_json_creator.py provides the option to generate .json files for pairwise analyses or protein multimers with ligands. Default behaviour is to provide pairwise, with protein-multimer comparisons requiring a configuration file.

title: 3  Using af3_json_creator.py for Protein-Protein Analyses
text:
Input File Formats
af3_json_creator.py provides the option to generate .json files for pairwise analyses or protein multimers. Default behaviour is to provide pairwise, with protein-multimer comparisons requiring a configuration file.

title: 4  Using af3_json_creator.py for Protein-Nucleotide Analyses
text:
Input File Formats
af3_json_creator.py provides the option to generate .json files for pairwise analyses or protein multimers with nucleotides e.g. DNA or RNA sequences. Default behaviour is to provide pairwise, with protein-multimer comparisons requiring a configuration file.

title: 5  Using af3_json_creator.py for Multi-Component Analyses
text:
Generating example .yaml Configuration File
A major advantage of using AlphaFold3 over AlphaFold2 is the ability to examine more complex or multi-component associations e.g. proteins with ligands and nucleotides. To assist in generating .json files for these more diverse scenarios the user can use an example .yaml configuration file and modify as required. This configuration file is then used as input to af3_json_creator.py
There are two example .yaml configuration files available, one which provides the option to add multi-components only e.g. protein, with ligand and nucleotides. The second is more advanced and also provides the option to add modifications to the provided proteins or nucleotides.
To generate the example .yaml use:
This will generate the example .yaml within the current directory called either example_config.yaml or example_config_advanced.yaml.

title: 3  Using af3_json_creator.py for Protein-Protein Analyses
text:
3.1 Monomer Analysis
To generate appropriate .json files for monomer analysis using AlphaFold3 e.g. multiple chain IDs, use the following command:
af3_json_creator.py protein-protein --fasta1 protein.fasta --monomer 4 --output-dir output
Where --fasta1 is a FASTA file containing a single protein sequence and --monomer is the number of chains you would like to examine.
